{"step_by_step_thinking": "A drug is considered counterfeit when it is deliberately and fraudulently mislabeled with respect to identity and/or source. This includes both branded and generic products. Counterfeits may include products with the correct or wrong ingredients, without active ingredients, with incorrect quantity of active ingredient, or with fake packaging. In this case, the drug is labeled as containing 500 mg of paracetamol, but it actually contains only 200 mg. This means the drug is mislabeled with respect to the quantity of the active ingredient, which fits the definition of a counterfeit drug.", "answer_choice": "A"}
